metadata.case_name: Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack & Anr. v. B.C. Patel & Co.

facts.text: Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 (Orissa Act XIV of 1947) received assent of Governor-General on April 26, 1947; Section 1 came into force immediately.
Notification issued on August 1, 1947, bringing rest of the Act into force in Province of Orissa.
Notification issued on August 14, 1947, appointing September 30, 1947, as date for Section 4(1) to come into force in Province of Orissa.
Feudatory State of Pallahara merged into Province of Orissa by covenant on January 1, 1948.
Government of Orissa, under Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947, issued notification on December 14, 1948, extending Orissa Sales Tax Act to erstwhile feudatory States including Pallahara.
Notification under Section 1(3) on March 1, 1949, bringing Sections 2 to 29 into force in added territories.

Notification under Section 4(1) on March 1, 1949: 'In exercise of the powers conferred by Sub-section (1) of Section 4 of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 (Orissa Act XIV of 1947) as applied to Orissa State, the Government of Orissa are pleased to appoint the 31st March, 1949, as the date with effect from which every dealer whose gross turnover during the year ending the 31st March, 1949, exceeded Rs. 5,000 shall be liable to pay tax under the said Act on sales effected after the said date.'
Respondents (Messrs. B.C. Patel & Co.), partnership firm at Pallahara, carry on business of collection and sale of Kendu leaves.
Respondents collected Kendu leaves in Orissa and sold to merchants in Calcutta, Madras etc. on receipt of orders; goods sent f.o.r. Talcher or f.o.r. Calcutta; bills sent to purchasers for payment.
Admitted that goods were delivered for consumption at places outside State of Orissa.

Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack assessed respondents for five quarters ending September 30, 1949; December 31, 1949 (pre-Constitution); June 30, 1950; September 30, 1950; December 31, 1950 (post-Constitution). Assessment orders dated May 31, 1951.
Respondents' appeals dismissed by Assistant Collector of Sales Tax, Orissa on April 12, 1952.
Respondents filed petition under Article 226 in Orissa High Court (O.J.C. No. 60 of 1952) praying for writ of certiorari quashing assessments and prohibiting realization.
Orissa High Court by judgment dated April 12, 1955, cancelled all assessment orders.
Special leave to appeal granted on January 17, 1956.

It was conceded that for period April 1, 1949 to January 26, 1950 (commencement of Constitution), respondents would be liable if valid notification under s.4(1) issued; this concedes gross turnover exceeded Rs.5,000 in year ending March 31, 1948.
Sales Tax authorities found gross turnover exceeded Rs.5,000 in year ending March 31, 1949.

legal_issues.text: Whether the notification dated March 1, 1949 under Section 4(1) of Orissa Sales Tax Act was valid, particularly as it referred to gross turnover in year ending March 31, 1949 instead of year immediately preceding commencement of the Act.
Whether assessments for pre-Constitution quarters valid under Section 4(2) even if Section 4(1) notification invalid.
Whether assessments for post-Constitution quarters valid in light of Article 286 of Constitution and Section 30 of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notification under s.4(1) valid; mistake in specifying year immaterial or severable; alternatively, liability under s.4(2). For post-Constitution, valid under Sales Tax Continuance Order 1950 per Bengal Immunity.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Orissa Sales Tax Act s.4(1), s.4(2); Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar

petitioner_arguments.text: Sales took place in Orissa; inter-State sales taxable under Continuance Order.

respondent_arguments.text: Notification under s.4(1) invalid as it contravened sub-section by using wrong year (ending March 31, 1949 instead of preceding commencement); no liability under s.4(1) or s.4(2) as mutually exclusive and s.4(2) barred if s.4(1) applicable.
Post-Constitution assessments invalid under Art.286(1) as sales outside Orissa (goods delivered for consumption outside).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Art.286; State of Bombay v. United Motors

court_reasoning.text: Notification under s.4(1) severable: part appointing March 31, 1949 valid; part specifying wrong year invalid and surplusage. Dealers determined by s.4(1) itself (year preceding commencement: 1947-48). Concession admits respondents' turnover exceeded Rs.5,000 in 1947-48.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Two portions severable; no difficulty in holding excess portion severable.

court_reasoning.text: Even if s.4(1) not apply, respondents liable under s.4(2) as turnover first exceeded Rs.5,000 in 1948-49 (year ending March 31, 1949), so liable from April 1, 1949.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sub-ss.(1) and (2) mutually exclusive by relevant periods; s.4(2) applies where turnover first exceeds in year after commencement.

court_reasoning.text: Post-Constitution assessments invalid: sales hit by Art.286(1)(a) Explanation (deemed outside Orissa as delivered for consumption outside) and s.30(1)(a)(i); Bengal Immunity confirms cl.1(a) ban independent of cl.2.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bans in Art.286 separate and independent.

holdings.text: Notification under s.4(1) valid insofar as appointing date March 31, 1949; invalid part severable.
Pre-Constitution assessments valid under s.4(1) or alternatively s.4(2).
Post-Constitution assessments invalid under Art.286(1)(a) and s.30(1)(a)(i).

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors (India) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.286(1) deems sales delivered for consumption outside as outside State.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.286 clauses independent; cl.1(a) ban applies to sales outside State even if inter-State.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Charging provision; determines dealer liability based on turnover thresholds and notification; s.30 incorporates Art.286 restrictions post-Constitution.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition; restricts State power to tax sales outside State or inter-State.

statutes_cited.name: Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to extend Act to feudatory States.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed in part: High Court order upheld quashing post-Constitution assessments (three quarters) as invalid under Art.286(1); reversed for pre-Constitution assessments (two quarters) as valid under s.4(1) or s.4(2). Parties to bear own costs in High Court and Supreme Court.

key_quotes.text: "We find no difficulty in holding that the portion of the notification which went beyond the powers conferred on the Government of Orissa is quite clearly and easily severable from that which was within its powers."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for upholding part of notification.

key_quotes.text: "These several bans may overlap in some cases but in their respective scope and operation they are separate and independent."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains independence of Art.286 clauses from Bengal Immunity.

key_quotes.text: "Sub-sections (1) and (2) are mutually exclusive only in the sense that they do not operate in the same field that is, the relevant periods for their application are different."
key_quotes.speaker: court
